page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY OF BALFRON
page.content: Balfron increased in population during the time of the Industrial Revolution, when the water-powered {cotton mill}was built near the River Endrick. Many{streets}owe their names to the industry- Cotton Street, Weavers Winnell, Spinners Street, Spokers Loan and Printers Row. The two mill owners{Buchanan and Dunmore}have the two longest streets named after them. Many of the houses in the older parts of the village have very distinctive long narrow gardens. This was to allow the cotton to be laid out for bleaching. With the introduction of steam power, the mill was closed and the building was used latterly for shirt-making early in the twentieth century. {Navvies}stayed in the area when the water pipeline was dug from Loch Katrine to Glasgow.
